Authors:
Alija Bajro Mujic, Nan Zheng, Kristy Kim, Joseph W.
Spatafora, Michael A. Castellano, Matthew E Smith
Title:
The Cedrus-associated truffle Trappeindia himalayensis is a
morphologically unique and phylogenetically divergent species of
Rhizopogon
Keywords:
Boletales; Cedrus; ectomycorrhiza; cryptic diversity;
sequestrate fungi; truffles
Abstract:
In the northwestern Himalayan Mountains of India,
villagers harvest a hypogeous, sequestrate fungus called Trappeindia
himalayensis that fruits in forests dominated by the ectomycorrhizal
tree Cedrus deodara (Himalayan Cedar). This truffle has unique
basidiospores that are ornamented with raised reticulation. Although
Trappeindia is regularly collected with Cedrus, the trophic mode and
phylogenetic affinity of this truffle are unknown. The original
description of Trappeindia himalayensis suggested that the gleba of this
species is similar to young specimens of Scleroderma (Boletales) whereas
the spores suggest a possible morphological link to Leucogaster
(Russulales) or Strobilomyces (Boletales). Here we present the first
molecular data for this unusual, Cedrus-associated truffle to clarify
its phylogenetic affinity. We show that despite the irregular,
ornamented spore morphology, Trappeindia himalayensis is resolved within
the genus Rhizopogon (Suillineae, Boletales) and represents a unique
lineage that has not been previously detected. This study highlights the
importance of generating sequence data from herbarium specimens in order
to identify fungal biodiversity and clarify the trophic modes of
underdocumented fungi.
